pr_title: Ensure CI is run in FIPS 140 approved only mode

timeline.message:
Ensure CI is run in FIPS 140 approved only mode

We were depending on the BouncyCastle FIPS own mechanics to set
itself in approved only mode since we run with the Security
Manager enabled. The check during startup seems to happen before we
set our restrictive SecurityManager though in
org.elasticsearch.bootstrap.Elasticsearch , and this means that
BCFIPS would not be in approved onlu mode, unless explicitly
configured so.

This commit sets the appropriate JVM property to explicitly set
BCFIPS in approved only mode and addresses a number of tests that
would fail in approved mode. Mainly:
- Tests that use PBKDF2 with a password less than 112 bits (14char)
- Tests that use a PKCS12 keystore and were not already muted.

It also changes a few unit tests where we would use bcrypt even in
FIPS 140 mode. These would still pass since we are bundling our own
bcrypt implementation, but are now changed to use FIPS 140 approved
algorithms instead for better coverage.

timeline.bodyText: I think these tests can have better coverage if we move them into ESTestCase#inFipsJvm so that they are always checked if fips is enabled.
timeline.author: ywangd

replies.bodyText:
I think it's better here. I feel like this is more explicit in its own test that has its own distinct purpose rather than burying it in another test (case).
We might get more coverage by moving them, but I don't understand the value of that - we only need to run them once to get the value we need.
replies.author: tvernum

replies.bodyText: I think it has some value, maybe not for CI, but for individual tests when you need run them locally so that you can be sure FIPS is always correctly configured by the property passed from CLI.
replies.author: ywangd

replies.bodyText:
I think it has some value, maybe not for CI,

The purpose is to cover CI ,do that we don't make any change in the feature that would lead to us not running CI in non approved mode.
I think the clarity of it being in it's own class makes sense and we should leave it here
replies.author: jkakavas

timeline.bodyText: The password was passwd which is different from SecuritySettingsSourceField.TEST_PASSWORD_SECURE_STRING. This and a few similar changes in other places are causing CI failure for this PR. I think the fix should be updating AbstractPrivilegeTestCase#setUser to use the new password as well.
timeline.author: ywangd

timeline.bodyText: Nit: The indentation is now inconsistent with all_indices_role. I do think the change here looks better. But I'd suggest we make the same change to all_indices_role as well.

timeline.message: Adjust a couple of more tests
Fix integration tests to use long passwords
Set fips_mode.enabled to true and set a defaut compliant password hashing algo for testclusters
Add password to keystores and make sure passwords are longer than 14 chars
Use long passwords in rest tests
Add keystore password when in fips mode, and fix some passwords

Skip REST YAML tests in FIPS 140 mode

Currently we don't have a way to selectively mute REST YAML tests
in FIPS 140 mode.

This commit introduces a new feature (fips_140) that can be used
in skip blocks to allow that.
Disable java rest tests for IDP in FIPS 140 mode
Use BuildParams instead of parsing the sysprop again

timeline.bodyText: Should we add "pbkdf2_stretch"for completeness?
timeline.author: BigPandaToo

replies.bodyText: yes, it's in my to do list. When I added the commit there was no pbkf2_stretch
replies.author: jkakavas

timeline.bodyText: Same as above. "pbkdf2_stretch"?
timeline.author: BigPandaToo

timeline.bodyText: Same as above. "pbkdf2_stretch"? There are few more cases below as well.
timeline.author: BigPandaToo

replies.bodyText: see previous comment
replies.author: jkakavas

timeline.bodyText: It may be outside of the scope of this PR, but do we plan to test Fips compatible PKCS12 keystores?
timeline.author: BigPandaToo

replies.bodyText:
There is no such thing as Fips compatible PKCS12 keystores, unfortunately*. See https://downloads.bouncycastle.org/fips-java/BC-FJA-UserGuide-1.0.2.pdf section 7 too. We document this in https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/current/fips-140-compliance.html#_tls_keystores_and_keys
* Technically, I think it might be possible to create a PKCS12 implementation that uses only PBES2 ( i.e. PBKDF2 ) for key derivation, but that would be outside the scope of this PR and our FIPS 140 support too.
replies.author: jkakavas

replies.bodyText: Aha, I must have mistaken FIPS compatible with FIPS approved only compatible...
replies.author: BigPandaToo

replies.bodyText: Not sure what you mean by compatible here, we can also discuss live
replies.author: jkakavas

timeline.message: disable test that assumes an OSS distribution
Mute tests that explicitly set the license to basic in FIPS 140, as fips mode is not supported in basic
Don't run ReloadSecureSettingsIT in fips mode. We could move this to xpack and enable TLS as a followup
Don't run geo tests with default distribution testclusters
Add password to the keystore of the docs testcluster, even when not in FIPS
mute mapper-extras tests until issue with trial is resolved
Adjust passwords in docs integration tests
factor out selecting a random hashing algo to a method of its own
Mute test that needs OSS cluster in FIPS 140 mode

timeline.bodyText: Doesn't look like we ever validate this password, so may be leaving the rang in {6, 19} would make sense just for completenes (since normally do allow shorter passwords)
timeline.author: BigPandaToo

replies.bodyText: This is not only about verification. Put user requests will trigger password hashing, which will fail in fips mode with short passwords
replies.author: jkakavas

replies.bodyText:
It doesn't look like it will. PutUserRequestBuilder does trigger a hasher, but we never get there. Looks like PutUserRequest is only used in tests.
Whith this said, I don't think it's a big problem to leave {14, 19} range here as long as we still have some tests covering the short allowed passwords when Fips is off.
replies.author: BigPandaToo

replies.bodyText:
It doesn't look like it will.

It will.
Try ./gradlew client:rest-high-level:integTest --tests="org.elasticsearch.client.SecurityIT.testPutUser" -Dtests.fips.enabled=true in this branch which fails with passwords < 14 characters.
We can further discuss this in real time if need be !
replies.author: jkakavas

replies.bodyText: Worked for me... Yes, I set the renge back to 6-10...
replies.author: BigPandaToo

replies.bodyText:
@BigPandaToo this test suite sets up a test cluster (client/rest-high-level/build.gradle)  and SecurityIT performs security API related tests with the high level client against that cluster. SecurityIT#testPutUser creates a random PutUserRequest and sends that request to the test cluster via the HLRC ( SecurityClient securityClient = highLevelClient().security(); )
When the test cluster processes this request it will hash that user password in the process of storing it to the security index ( see RestPutUserAction#innerPrepareRequest which triggers the hashing ) . This hashing will fail when PBKDF2 is used and an exception will be thrown.
If you don't get the failure, you either not run in FIPS mode ( -Dtests.fips.enabled=true ) or you don't run the test from this branch. You cannot try this in i.e. master as master doesn't yet contain the fix which is the reason for this PR and sets the test cluster correctly in fips mode )
Hope this makes more sense now
replies.author: jkakavas

replies.bodyText: We agreed on why this change in the test is necessary over a chat, as such I'm resolving the comment
replies.author: jkakavas

timeline.bodyText: Do all these tests fail in FIPS AO? It just doen't look like we are really get to any hashing here.

replies.bodyText: Same as above, creating a user involves hashing the password for storage.

timeline.message: Expect warnings when running with default distribution
Use appropriate length SecretKey for EC2, as it is used for key generation and should be > 112 bits in fips mode
Change GCS RSA keys to 2048bits so that tests don't fail in FIPS mode
Mute CCR test downgrading to basic in FIPS mode
Mute tests in fips when security is disabled
Ensure Kerberos fixture runs with fips 140-2 approved enctypes
use long passwords in kerberos tests
mute tests instead of all the tasks
Mutes qa tests that fail in CI until we can investigate more

Allow ESRestTestClient to trust certificates

ESRestTestCase rest clients could only be configured to trust
the certificate authorities that were contained in a truststore. In
certain cases (like in fips mode where JKS/PKCS12 keystores) cannot
be used, it's beneficial to be able to trust specific certificate
authorities (indicated by the CA PEM endoded certificate)
Adjust reindex from remote QA test to use PEM CA cert instead of a PKCS12 store
reference issue in muted CCR tests
set license to trial for testclusters as we can't use fips mode in basic. All the tests that require basic license are already muted in fips mode so they won't be affected

Disable bwc tests in fips mode as there arent' many ( only 7.11 ) versions that can be run in a correctly configured FIPS 140-2 JVM and we are lacking granural control of which bwc versions can be used
use long enough azure.client.key in tests
use long enough ec2 access keys in tests
Change docker integ tests to use PEM key/certificates instead of keystores so that these can be run in fips mode
Change remote-clusters integ tests to use PEM key/certificates instead of keystores so that these can be run in fips mode
Fix all s3 fixture related tests by using the correct access key
